instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .
definitions.P3V3G3S_EN: What is P3V3G3S_EN? P3VG3S_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_G3S power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.54A - 5V
threads.message:
Hello!

The Macbook comes wet in several areas and after analyzing the power-up sequence, it has the following voltages (I'm omitting some that are present):

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0-1.8 VARIES
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0-1.8 VARIES
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0-3.3 VARIES
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0-3V VARIES
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3S_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>P1V8G3S_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0V

With that consumption, the PMIC and T2 area is heated.

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.54A - 5V
threads.message:
Continuously varying, or cycling in seconds?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> not stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.54A - 5V
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> not stable = 8.40V goes up to 10.30V and goes back down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.54A - 5V
threads.message:
Did you disconnect the battery?
Test the board alone on the desk.

I bet you still have something affected by corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.54A - 5V
threads.message: The voltages that I have posted are with the board powered by power supply and BY3200.
